titlestmt.titleproper: James H. Etheridge and family collection
titlestmt.author: Toby A. Appel

publicationstmt.publisher: Medical Historical Library, Harvey Cushing / John Hay Whitney Medical Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 30, 2019 at 02:01

did.unittitle: James H. Etheridge and family collection

repository.corpname: Medical Historical Library, Harvey Cushing / John Hay Whitney Medical Library

langmaterial.language: Materials are in English except for some diplomas in Latin.

did.abstract: James H. Etheridge was a gynecologist who became Professor of Obstetrics and Gynecology at Rush Medical College. The collection contains biographical materials, correspondence of Etheridge, correspondence of Etheridge's wife's family (including the correspondence of Heman G. Powers, a Chicago businessman), Etheridge's writings, his patient records, ephemera from medical societies, photographs, and certificates and diplomas.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: James Henry Etheridge, gynecologist, was born in St. Johnsville, New York, March 20, 1844. His physician father, Francis B. Etheridge, taught J. H. Etheridge medicine before the latter entered Rush Medical College, Chicago, in 1866. After graduation in 1869, Etheridge began a general practice in Evanston, Illinois. In 1870, he married Harriet Elizabeth Powers, of Evanston, daughter of wealthy businessman Heman G. Powers and Sarah Throop Powers. They traveled abroad and and he visited hospitals in London. On his return in 1871, he set up practice in Chicago and became part of the teaching faculty of Rush Medical College. At first, he was a successful general practitioner, and then he specialized in gynecology. In 1889, he became Professor of Gynecology at Rush Medical College, and in 1892, Professor of Obstetrics and Gynecology. He was active in medical organizations and served as President of the Chicago Medical Society and the Chicago Gynecological Society. At the height of his career, he died suddenly on February 9, 1899. He was known as a man of good nature and wit, and as a skillful and rapid operator.

Heman George Powers, wealthy Chicago businessman and father-in-law to James H. Etheridge, was born in Keeseville, New York in 1820. He married Sarah Throop in 1843 in Vergenne, Vermont. About 1857, he moved to Chicago and built up a large wholesale grocery business under the name Durand Bros. and Powers. The business was destroyed in the Chicago fire of 1871. Powers then entered the banking business and became president of a bank in Chicago. In retirement, he lived in Evanston, Illinois, and spent time at a farm he owned in Wisconsin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers contain correspondence of J. H. Etheridge from 1894 until his death in 1899, correspondence of the Powers and Throop families back to the 1850s, medical case records and payment ledgers, talks and published articles, Rush Medical College ephemera, medical society ephemera, diplomas and certificates including some awarded to Etheridge's father, photographs, and the many obituaries written on Etheridge.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into 8 series: 1. Biographical information /Obituaries. 2. Correspondence of James H. Etheridge. 3. Powers/Throop family correspondence. 4. J. H. Etheridge writings. 5. Organizations and societies. 6. Medical practice. 7. Oversize box: Additional patient records, correspondence, and miscellany. 8. Flat box: Large photographs, certificates, and diplomas.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by a descendant, James Grant Young, from the estate of Margaret Grant Young, 2017.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Additional materials related to James H. Etheridge were donated by James Grant Young, from the estate of Margaret Grant Young, to the Rush University Medical Center Archives.

did.unittitle: Biographical information /Obituaries
Correspondence of Etheridge Grant on the disposal of J.H. Etheridge's Personal effects

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Etheridge Grant was a descendent of J.H. and Harriet (Hattie) Etheridge. Their daughter Fanny married John MacGregor Grant.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Folder contains the handwritten Resolutions as sent to Etheridge's family and an issue The Corpuscle (April 1899), the alumni journal of Rush Medical College, with the printed resolution.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Corpuscle was the "Official Organ of the Alumni Association of Rush Medical College, Chicago, Ill." The article, "James Henry Etheridge, A.M., M.D.: In Memoriam" (volume 8, pp. 273-276 and portrait) was presented to the faculty by Prof. James B. Herrick.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Newspaper clippings and printed report, "Monthly Meetings of the Alumnae Association of the Illinois Training School for Nurses," February 2, 1899 [sic], containing an obituary of Etheridge on page 8. For ten years Etheridge had been lecturer and physician to the School.

did.unittitle: Caricature of Etheridge and poem on minced pie, by C.J.P.U.
Other publications that mention Etheridge
The Presbyterian Hospital of the City of Chicago, Bulletin

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains a history of the hospital that mentions J. H. Etheridge.

did.unittitle: James H. Etheridge - photographs
Correspondence of James H. Etheridge

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains only correspondence from 1894 to 1899. The alphabetical files contain mainly letters received, although there is an occasional draft of a letter by Etheridge. Among his correspondents were women patients. Etheridge asked patients to write to him on the anniversary of their operations.

The incoming correspondence was housed in two boxes of Amberg's Popular Letter File sold by Amberg File & Index Co., Chicago. Many of the letters were not accurately filed under the proper letter in the index.
Someone, likely Mrs. Etheridge, who lived into the 1920s, annotated a number of the letters.
In Box 4 there are carbons of typed correspondence by date sent by Dr. Etheridge from September 1897 to his death in February 1899.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: R. M. Stone, M.D. was a physician in Omaha, Nebraska and his wife, Mary, was a patient of Etheridge. The case was discussed in detail.

Correspondence concerning calcium carbide in operations for cancer of the cervix

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In the issue of Journal of the American Medical Association for July 2, 1898, Etheridge had published "A Note on the Treatment of Carcinoma of the Uterus," in which he asked for information from others on treatment by calcium carbide. These responces from physicians were placed in a file by Etheridge.

did.unittitle: Correspondence: "Military"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These materials were grouped by Etheridge. He had served in the Civil War and had later served in the First Brigade, Illinois National Guard.

did.unittitle: Correspondence: "Military"
Carbons of letters by James H. Etheridge

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bound volume of carbon copies of typed letters by Etheridge arranged chronologically, September 20, 1897-December 5, 1898. Volume contains 1004 numbered pages plus an index at the beginning of the volume. See next folder.

did.unittitle: Carbons of letters by James H. Etheridge

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Folder containing unbound carbon copies of letters from December 5, 1898 to February 9, 1899, the day of his death. Carbons are paged from 1 to 103.

did.unittitle: Powers/Throop family correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This is correspondence from Harriet (Hattie) Powers Etheridge's side of the family, collected by Hattie Etheridge and her heirs. The letters were stored in several boxes of Amberg's Patent Indexes. Hattie Etheridge was the daughter of Heman G. Powers and Sarah (Throop) Powers. The bulk of this collection consists of letters to Hattie Etheridge's mother and father, Sarah Throop Powers and Heman G. Powers. Heman G. Powers's correspondence includes information on his various business dealings. The series also contains some letters by and to Hattie Etheridge, her children, and other relatives and friends.

did.unittitle: Correspondence of Harriet (Hattie) Powers Etheridge and children

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Harriet (Hattie) Elizabeth Powers was the daughter of Heman G. Powers and Sarah (Throop) Powers. She was born in 1848 and married James H. Etheridge on June 22, 1870. Her daughters were Fanny Etheridge (Grant) and Emily (or Emma) Etheridge (Brewer)(1877-1924). As of 1920, she was living in Chicago with Emily and Emily's husband William Brewer.

did.unittitle: J. H. Etheridge writings
Articles/Reprints
Articles/Reprints

J.H. Etheridge, "A Case of Uterine Myofibroma by Enucleation and Drainage through the Cavum Uteri," W.S.O.&G.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Entire bound volume of the Proceedings of the Western Association of Obstetricians and Gynecologists , 1893-1894. Etheridge's presentation is on pp. 37-41.

did.unittitle: "Menstruation," typescript
Manuscript draft obituary of William Wright Jaggard (1857-1896)
Presentation to a society on fever
"Ode upon the occasion of receiving -- a delicious maple caramel cake"
James H. Etheridge and Harriet E. Etheridge, "Our Little Fanny"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Biographical Notes on our first little Daughter, born May 23d. 1871. By J.H. and H.E. Etheridge." Leather volume, labelled in gold leaf, "Our Little Fanny, contains entries on Fanny's early years, photographs of Dr. and Mrs. Etheridge and baby Fanny, and a lock of Fanny's hair. The Etheridges later had another daughter, Emma (or Emily).

did.unittitle: Organizations and societies
Rush Medical College, Annual Announcements

unittitle.title: The Corpuscle, edited by the Students of Rush Medical College

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Five issues. Issues contain references to faculty members including Etheridge. See Box 1 for another issue containing an obituary of Etheridge.

did.unittitle: Rush Medical College ephemera

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains a new year's card, clippings, and a small engraving of Rush Medical College. Three large photographs, one of Rush Medical College, and the other two of Etheridge operating are in Box 10.

did.unittitle: American Medical Association Annual Meeting, Denver, ephemera
American Medical Association Annual Meeting, St. Louis, ephemera

Congress of American Physicians and Surgeons, Washington, D.C., ephemera
Obstetrical and gynecological societies ephemera
State and local medical societies ephemera
Annual Report, Illinois Training School for Nurses

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Etheridge was a member of the Advisory Board.

did.unittitle: Other organizations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Among the items is an 1895 "Private Report from the Physicians' Business Bureau" that listed local people with poor credit.

did.unittitle: Medical practice

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains bound volumes in folders that relate to Etheridge's medical practice. The record of Etheridge's medical practice is incomplete. See also folders in Box 9.

did.unittitle: Case histories

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this bound volume (33x21 cm), Etheridge wrote a full account of his cases and treatment. The volume begins with a few pages of notes on a course of anatomy and physiology he attended in Ann Arbor, Michigan, in 1866. Some documents are inserted in the volume, including a letter and case history of Mrs. Hubbard sent by Dr. E. L. Homes, March 10, 1880

did.unittitle: Patient ledger

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bound volume (31x14 cm) lists patients by day, with charges and payments. There is an index to names at the beginning of the volume. The book had little information on diagnoses and treatments.

did.unittitle: Account of travel to London

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bound volume (24x20 cm) with an account of Etheridge's travels in London. Etheridge married Harriet Powers in 1870. He noted that they had spent the months of September through the most of November visiting Paris, Switzerland, Italy, Austria, Bavaria, Wurtemberg, Saxony, Russia, the Rhine and Belgium, and had now (November 26) arrived in London. "Our chief object here is to benefit me, by walking the hospital & gaining all the information I can here elicit professionally. The chief object of this book is [to] note down things of interest..." Most of the remainder of the book contains lists of menus and recipes.

did.unittitle: St. Vincent Hall prescriptions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Possibly St. Vincent Hall was a dispensary. The bound volume in pencil (20x16 cm) gives the date, the name of the patient, and the prescription.

did.unittitle: Patient ledger

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Large bound volume (37x23cm) containing an index of names, and a list of patients, dates of visits, amounts billed, and amounts paid.

did.unittitle: Patient ledger
Cash book

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This bound volume (22x14 cm.) stamped "Cash" in gold leaf on the front cover, has been organized by month. For each month, Etheridge listed several entries for "Office" followed by the names of various people and amounts of money.

did.unittitle: Record of patients and operations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bound pre-printed volume (23x15 cm.) with "Dr. Etheridge" in gold leaf on the cover. There is no indication about the publisher. The open pages have columns for date, name of patient, name of referring] physician, fees, operation, arrival, and remarks. Only a small portion of the volume was used.

did.unittitle: Cases numbered 2019-2862

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The bound volume is a pre-printed case book for diseases of women. It has spaces for name, date, age, whether married, number of children, number of miscarriages, general appearance and condition, family history, symptoms (broken down by type), menstruation,...diagnosis, and treatment. There is no publishing information for this pre-printed book. Etheridge entered an index at the beginning. There is a pasted piece on the cover which says, "Mrs. H. L. Humphrey, Masseuse, 4943 Woodlawn Ave."
